poem:
Trade Winds

Planes loop overhead like tangled kites,  
their shadows stitching borders  
to torn fabrics of land and sky.  
In the echo of rotors and rhetoric,  
a hush descends on a Paris stage—  
contracts grounded, stands stripped,  
tight-lipped allies trading glances,  
weighing silence against sirens.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Iran and Israel trade attacks as conflict enters fourth day – live updates 2.57pm BST The office of French Prime Minister has commented after France shut down the main Israeli company stands at the Paris Airshow on Monday for refusing to remove attack weapons from display, in a move condemned by Israel and highlighting tensions between the traditional allies. A spokesperson for the office of Francois Bayrou said it had told all exhibitors ahead of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
